bibl.title: Letter from M.S. Lombard to Henry Rose Carter, November 17, 1922

div1.p: Lombard requests Carter's advice on possible yellow fever cases.

div1.head: Letter from M.S. Lombard to Henry Rose Carter, November 17, 1922
div1.opener:
MOBILE QUARANTINE
FORT MORGAN, ALABAMA
I. H. B.
Mobile
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
MOBILE QUARANTINE
Fort Morgan, Ala.,
November 17, 1922.
Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
2121 California Street, N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
To-days mail was one of the few worth awhile
receiving, for as a wonderful and welcome surprise, I
received your thoughtful letter and very much appreciated
articles on yellow fever - I shall read your writing with
great interest and no less profit I am sure and shall
return it only when I have memorized a good deal of it.
What may be of greater interest to you, than the reported
yellow fever case from Paramaribo are the two cases of
“something” that during the latter part of October, I took
off one of the best ships that fly the American flag. I am
simply stuck, Dr. Carter, and I need your advice badly.
I take the liberty to enclose a part of the histories and
graphic charts of the cases together with a summary of the
laboratory findings, which I wish you would consider and
advise me. I am still wondering whether we have yellow
fever or estivo autumnal malaria or both, as I am inclined
to believe, in each instance. Shortly after the admission
of the patients, I asked two Mobile Doctors to see the cases
and they both agreed with me, that the patients were both
yellow fever. Then the continued search of blood smears
revealed the malaria parasites in Chancy's case. A short
time ago, Adie had a typical malarial attack save the chill
prior to each febrile paroxim, which is understood however.
I fully appreciate the sanitary importance in reaching a
correct diagnosis in these cases, hence your opinion most
desirable. To be sure that no error has been made on my
part, I am also sending you part of the blood slides taken,
which I wish you would have examined and check me up.

I am not trying to pose as a finish laboratory
technician, and if I have slipped up on something, it will
be to my advantage to know it as it is to the Service
interest to know exactly what we are dealing with. If you

should find it practicable to discuss the subject with
Dr. Long of the Quarantine Division, other reported facts
may come to light, as I have made an effort to keep the
Bureau fully informed of circumstances, as I see them.

It is unfortunate indeed, that I have not all
the clinical data prepared for typing, but should you want
to review the entire histories, please advise me as I expect
to have these up to date by the time I would hear from you.

Thanking you in advance for the trouble I am
about to put you to, and assuring you of my appreciation
for your courtesy, I shall close.

With kindest regards to yourself and daughter,
from me and mine, I am,

closer.seg:
P. S. I just received orders for the U. S. Marine Hospital No.5
Chicago Ill. I have not lost interest in these cases so
please let me hear from you. I expect to leave shortly
M S L
